filename: Sample Written History and Physical Examination

key_details.A third heard sound is heard at the apex: An extra heart sound (called S3) is heard at the bottom tip of the heart.
key_details.ASCVD: A type of heart disease where arteries harden and narrow due to plaque buildup.
key_details.Abdominal bruit: A whooshing sound heard in the belly, usually from blood flow through a narrowed artery.
key_details.BUN/Creatinine: Blood tests used to check kidney function.
key_details.Bimanual examination reveals no palpable: Two-handed internal exam shows no felt uterus, ovaries, or lumps.
key_details.Bunionectomy: Surgery to remove a bunion, a bony bump on the foot.
key_details.Carotid artery upstroke is normal bilate: Pulses in the neck arteries feel normal on both sides, without unusual whooshing sounds.
key_details.Cranial nerves II-XII are normal: The major nerves coming directly from the brain are all working normally.
key_details.Cystic changes are noted in the breasts: Fluid-filled sacs are seen in both breasts.
key_details.Cystic changes of breasts: Presence of fluid-filled sacs in the breasts.
key_details.Early surgical menopause: Menopause that happened earlier than natural due to surgery.
key_details.Epigastric pain: Pain in the upper stomach area, just below the ribs.
key_details.FH of early ASCVD: Family history of early hardening of the arteries (a type of heart disease).
key_details.Fundoscopic examination reveals normal v: Eye exam shows normal blood vessels in the back of the eye with no bleeding.
key_details.GERD sx: Symptoms of acid reflux, where stomach acid comes up into your throat.
key_details.Gait and cerebellar function are also no: Walking pattern and the brain's ability to coordinate movement are normal.
key_details.Gastro-esophageal reflux disease: A condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus), causing heartburn.
key_details.Genitourinary: Relating to the genital and urinary organs.
key_details.HEENT: Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, and Throat.
key_details.HMG Co-reductases: A type of medication, often called statins, used to lower cholesterol.
key_details.Jugular venous pressure is measured as 8: Pressure in the neck veins is measured at 8 centimeters when the patient is at a 45-degree angle.
key_details.Lumbosacral back pain: Pain in the lower back area.
key_details.Motor and sensory examination of the upp: Tests of muscle strength, movement, and feeling in the arms and legs are normal.
key_details.NSAID use: Use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, a type of pain reliever.
key_details.Nasal mucosa normal: Inside lining of the nose is normal.
key_details.Neurological: Relating to the nervous system, including the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
key_details.No cyanosis, clubbing, or edema are note: No bluish skin color, abnormal finger/toe shape, or swelling due to fluid.
key_details.No fourth heart sound or rub are heard: No other abnormal heart sounds (like S4 or a friction rub) are heard.
key_details.No palpable nodes in the cervical, supra: No swollen lymph nodes can be felt in the neck, above the collarbone, armpits, or groin.
key_details.Normal rectal sphincter tone: Normal muscle control around the rectum.
key_details.OTC non-steroidal analgesic use: Use of over-the-counter pain relievers that are not steroids.
key_details.Oral pharynx is normal without erythema: Back of the throat is normal, without redness or pus or fluid.
key_details.PMI is in the 5th inter-costal space at: The strongest heartbeat is felt in the fifth space between the ribs, in the middle of the collarbone line.
key_details.Pelvic examination reveals normal extern: Exam of the female reproductive organs shows normal external parts, and the vagina and cervix appear normal when viewed with a speculum.
key_details.Penicillin allergy: An allergic reaction to the antibiotic penicillin.
key_details.Peripheral pulses in the femoral, poplit: Pulses in the groin, behind the knee, front of the shin, top of the foot, upper arm, and wrist are all normal.
key_details.Pupils equally round, 4 mm, reactive to: Eyes respond normally to light and focusing.
key_details.Recent onset HTN: High blood pressure that started recently.
key_details.Reflexes are normal and symmetrical bila: Automatic body reactions are normal and equal on both sides in the arms and legs.
key_details.Stool is brown and guaiac negative: Stool is normal color and has no hidden blood.
key_details.Systolic ejection murmur: A specific type of heart murmur heard when the heart is pumping blood out.
key_details.TAH with BSO: Surgical removal of the uterus and both ovaries.
key_details.Total abdominal hysterectomy: Surgery to remove the uterus through an incision in the abdomen.
key_details.Trachea is midline: Windpipe is in the normal central position.
key_details.Tympanic membranes and external auditory: Eardrums and outer ear canals are normal.
key_details.alleviating factors: Things that make the problem better.
key_details.analgesic: A medication used to relieve pain.
key_details.angina pectoris: Chest pain that happens when the heart muscle doesn't get enough blood.
key_details.aortic stenosis: Narrowing of the main heart valve (aortic valve) that controls blood flow from the heart to the body.
key_details.aspirin: A common medication used to thin the blood and reduce clot formation.
key_details.associated symptoms: Other problems that happen at the same time.
key_details.baseline EKG: An initial recording of your heart's electrical activity.
key_details.bowel sounds are normal in quality and i: Normal sounds of digestion heard in the belly.
key_details.bruit is heard in the right paraumbilica: A whooshing sound from blood flow is heard near the belly button on the right side.
key_details.cardiac catheterization: A procedure where a thin tube is inserted into a blood vessel and guided to the heart to look at the arteries and check heart function.
key_details.carotid upstroke: The pulse felt in the neck artery.
key_details.cervical or supraclavicular areas: Areas in the neck or above the collarbone.
key_details.cholesterol-lowering medication: Medication to reduce levels of cholesterol in the blood.
key_details.cimetidine: A medication used to treat stomach ulcers.
key_details.claudication: Leg pain or cramping that happens with exercise due to poor blood flow.
key_details.clear to auscultation and percussion bil: Lungs sound clear when listened to with a stethoscope and tapped on both sides.
key_details.congestive heart failure: A condition where the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, leading to fluid buildup.
key_details.coronary artery disease: Narrowing or blockage of the arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle.
key_details.crackles heard in the lung bases bilater: Crackling sounds heard in the lower parts of both lungs.
key_details.diuretics: Medications, often called 'water pills', that help your body get rid of excess fluid.
key_details.electrolytes: Important salts and minerals in your blood that help your body work properly.
key_details.epigastric pain: Pain in the upper middle part of the belly.
key_details.exacerbating factors: Things that make the problem worse.
key_details.exertional dyspnea: Shortness of breath that happens with physical activity.
key_details.fibrocystic breast disease: A common, non-cancerous condition where breasts feel lumpy or rope-like.
key_details.grade 2/6 systolic decrescendo murmur: A soft heart sound (murmur) that gets quieter as the heart squeezes.
key_details.hormone replacement therapy: Medication to replace hormones, often after menopause.
key_details.hospitalization is indicated: Staying in the hospital is necessary.
key_details.hypertensive retinopathy: Damage to the blood vessels in the back of the eye due to high blood pressure.
key_details.ischemic cardiac origin: Coming from the heart due to a lack of blood flow.
key_details.left ventricular dysfunction: The main pumping chamber of your heart (left ventricle) is not working as well as it should.
key_details.left ventricular hypertrophy: Thickening of the walls of the heart's main pumping chamber.
key_details.liver span is 8 cm by percussion: The size of the liver is measured as 8 centimeters by tapping on the abdomen.
key_details.myocardial infarction: A heart attack, which is damage to the heart muscle due to a blocked blood supply.
key_details.myocardial ischemia: Damage to the heart muscle because of insufficient blood flow.
key_details.nitrates: Medications that relax blood vessels and improve blood flow, often used for chest pain.
key_details.nocturia: Waking up at night to urinate.
key_details.non-invasive tests: Medical tests that do not involve breaking the skin or entering the body.
key_details.occlusion: A blockage in a blood vessel.
key_details.orthopnea: Shortness of breath that happens when lying flat.
key_details.palpable pain: Pain that can be felt by touching the area.
key_details.palpitations: Feeling like your heart is racing or skipping beats.
key_details.paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea: Sudden shortness of breath that wakes you up at night.
key_details.peptic ulcer disease: Sores that form in the lining of the stomach or first part of the small intestine.
key_details.pertinent risk factors: Important things that increase your chance of getting a condition.
key_details.platelet inhibitors: Medications that prevent blood cells called platelets from clumping together to form clots.
key_details.premature CAD: Heart artery disease that develops earlier than expected, often due to genetics.
key_details.pretest probability: The likelihood of a disease being present before a specific test is done.
key_details.radiated: Spread from one area to another.
key_details.renal artery: The artery that supplies blood to the kidney.
key_details.renovascular hypertension: High blood pressure caused by narrowing of the arteries to the kidneys.
key_details.sclera and conjunctiva normal: White part of the eye and the lining of the eyelid are normal.
key_details.second right inter-costal space: Second space between the ribs on the right side.
key_details.secondary cause of hypertension: High blood pressure that is caused by another medical condition.
key_details.thyroid gland is normal without masses: Thyroid gland in the neck is normal with no lumps.
key_details.unstable angina: A severe type of chest pain from the heart that is worsening and can happen even at rest, indicating a higher risk of heart attack.
key_details.valvular heart disease: A problem with one or more of the heart's valves.
key_details.ventriculogram: A special X-ray of the heart's pumping chambers.
key_details.volume overload: Having too much fluid in the body.
key_details.wall motion abnormalities: Areas of the heart muscle that do not contract normally.

personal_takeaways:
Pamela, your main concern is the chest pain you've been having. It sounds like a type of chest pain called angina, which means your heart isn't getting enough blood. Because this pain has been happening more often and even when you're resting, it's considered a serious type of chest pain that is worsening and needs immediate attention to prevent a heart attack.

You have several factors that increase your risk for heart problems, including a family history where heart artery disease developed earlier than expected, high blood pressure, and having your uterus and ovaries surgically removed at a younger age.

We also see signs that suggest your heart's main pumping chamber might not be working as well as it should, possibly leading to fluid buildup and shortness of breath. Your recent high blood pressure, combined with a whooshing sound heard in your belly, makes us wonder if there's a narrowing in the arteries leading to your kidneys, which can cause high blood pressure. There's also a specific extra heart sound that we'll investigate further to check your heart valves.

Beyond your heart, we've noted you have common issues like pain in your upper stomach, lower back pain, and non-cancerous fluid-filled sacs in your breasts. You also have an allergy to penicillin.

The plan involves closely monitoring your heart, giving you medications to prevent blood clots and relieve your pain, and helping to lower your blood pressure. We'll also schedule a special procedure to look directly at your heart arteries. Once you're stable and discharged, we'll focus on a healthy lifestyle with diet and exercise to manage your heart health long-term, and potentially start medication to lower your cholesterol if needed.

1. Follow a Healthy Eating Plan: Adopt and stick to a low-fat diet. This helps manage your cholesterol and overall heart health.
2. Start an Exercise Program: Begin an appropriate exercise program as advised by your doctor when you are ready. Regular physical activity is crucial for your heart and overall well-being.
3. Work Towards Weight Loss: Participate in a weight loss program. Losing weight can significantly improve your heart issues and blood pressure.
4. Take Your Aspirin (if prescribed): If your doctor prescribes it, take aspirin regularly as directed. This medication helps to prevent blood clots and reduce your risk of a heart attack.
5. Take Your Nitrates (if prescribed): If your doctor prescribes them, take nitrates to help reduce your chest pain and improve blood flow.
6. Take Your Diuretics (if prescribed): If your doctor prescribes them, take diuretics (water pills) as directed. These will help your body get rid of excess fluid, which can reduce your shortness of breath and help lower your blood pressure.
7. Take Cholesterol-Lowering Medication: If your cholesterol levels are high and your doctor prescribes it, take cholesterol-lowering medication as directed. This helps protect your heart arteries.
